Jesse Mu and Shikhar Murty

Language is a crucial way for humans to teach other humans. Can we use language to teach machines?

Learning to Influence Multi-Agent Interaction

Annie Xie

We introduce a framework for multi-agent interaction that represents the low-level policies of non-stationary agents with high-level latent strategies.
Continue reading

Bootleg: Chasing the Tail with Self-Supervised Named Entity Disambiguation

Laurel Orr, Megan Leszczynski, Simran Arora, Neel Guha, Xiao Ling, Sen Wu, and Chris Ré

Identifying rare people, places, and things (entities) in text is a critical problem in AI, especially as the majority of entities are rare. We address this problem in our self-supervised system Bootleg. Bootleg learns to reason over entity types and relations for improved rare entity performance.
Continue reading

Measuring Bias in NLP (with Confidence!)

Kawin Ethayarajh

When estimating bias in NLP, there is usually uncertainty. We propose capturing this uncertainty using confidence intervals, finding that the datasets currently used to measure bias are too small to conclusively identify it – except in the most egregious cases.
Continue reading

Learning to Fix Programs from Error Messages

Michihiro Yasunaga

We study how to use machine learning to repair programs from error messages, and introduce a promising approach that leverages program-feedback graphs and self-supervised learning.
Continue reading

Adapting on the Fly to Test Time Distribution Shift

Marvin Zhang

We meta-learn models that can use unlabeled test data to adapt to group distribution shift.
Continue reading

The Coming Wave of ML Systems

Chris Ré, Piero Molino, Dan Fu, Karan Goel, Fiodar Kazhamakia, and Matei Zaharia

Introducing the Stanford MLSys Seminar Series on the frontier of machine learning systems. How does ML change the modern programming stack, and what does it mean for how people will build and deploy applications in the future?
Continue reading

GTI: Learning to Generalize Across Long-Horizon Tasks from Human Demonstrations

Ajay Mandlekar, Danfei Xu

We developed Generalization Through Imitation (GTI) - an algorithm for learning visuomotor control from human demonstrations and generalizing to new long-horizon tasks by leveraging latent compositional structures.
Continue reading
